Using 100% of you brain at once is called a Grand Mal Seizure, if that were to happen to you then you would lose consciousness and start experiencing violent muscle contractions. A few other things may also occur during this like defecating and urinating on yourself as you lose muscle control, unresponsiveness when the contractions stop, and a serious headache owing to the uncontrolled bioelectric activity in your nervous system that provoked the seizure. This can be caused by epilepsy, extreme low blood sugar, a stroke, or a sufficiently high fever. I suspect you’re referring to the old 10% myth that became common in the United States after some sensationalist articles mentioned it. The truth is that the actual percentage of your brain that you use, in terms of parts that relate to thought and activities, is a lot higher and varies based on what you’re doing. After all you don’t want to be using every single neuron at once as doing so would again cause a seizure, you instead want to be using the section that has the learn muscle memory for walking while you’re walking, the bit that remembers the taste of coca cola when you’re drinking coca cola, and the part that differentiates colors when trying to observe objects in your surroundings. In point of fact the old 10% myth is based off an intentional misrepresentation of an article that estimated neurons, the cells which do the thinking, only make up about 10% of the brains total mass with the rest being support and other types of cells.

Ahem. Burn-out? What you are suggesting is that the brain working at its maximum capability is anywhere in the realms of either desirable or efficent. Both are great to have and both come at a cost. If you want the brain to be desirable, then you must allow the brain to operate at peak efficiency with the ability to cross-synapse with minimal energy use. That’s why a human brain looks like this.  Note all the squiggly bits (scientific term there) that make up the brain. The squiggly bits have a better name .. its referred to as folds. The ridges are referred to as gyri and the folds are called sulci As you might guess the more folds you have the more surface area you can compact into the brain and the more brain space you can employ and connect with quickly. Other animals have much smoother brains with nowhere near as many folds, so cramming that much in works to an efficiency ratio.  As you can see without too much squinting, the rat or mouse has a largely smooth brain, the wallaby still has a lot of smoothness, the macaque and mandrill may be monkeys but they dont have a full set of folds to make high efficiency critical thinking decisions when required, whereas the bear and giraffe seem to have what it takes. The one to take notice of in these brain pictures is the cat and the cheetah followed by the lion. Both the cat and the lion have a series of distinct folds where the cheetah doesnt have that explicit need, because the requirement for the cheetah is specialist high speed capture. Whereas the lion and cat are stalking predators. Each is guided to provide for the needs of the animal to maximum efficiency for the task. If the cheetah had a greater series of folds upstairs he might also be suffering from burnout on the savannah as high folds also produces greater internal heat. If you had 100% usage of the brain, it would be the same as pumping steroids, you’d look great for a limited period but suffer long term with design stress, as the muscles of the body end up being overworked, so too do the neurons and nerves of the brain. So you could take your magic pill as seen in recent cinema and do things far beyond the capabilities of ‘mere mortals’.  But it would come at a cost, the longer term performance of the body and the lifespan and sanity of the person concerned. There are tricks around this and that has to do with implants and compensation, but that’s cyborg implementation vs natural expansion .. and another topic for another day.

Okay, someone actually advocated violence with regard to anyone coming up with the trope about only using 10% of our brain, and if we could use it all, telepathic powers, etc., would appear. The brain is an extraordinarily complex association engine, a pile of neutrons firing as stimulated by the senses but also its own activity. When we talk about "using all our brain," we often are thinking about conscious use. However, the brain functions all the time, on a scale that is vast compared to what we are conscious of. So, in a question like this, we have an ego, the creation of a small part of the brain, asking what "it" can do if "it" can "use all my brain at once." There is a whole concept of reality there, a common one, to be sure, but divorced from real possibility. Let me ask the question differently. What can the brain do? There is no fixed limit, under some conditions. One of those conditions is that not just one brain is involved. When people communicate, by which I mean much more than words, the operating entity is not limited by the individual self and its petty ideas. Since the activity of humanity is mediated through intelligence, an individual brain is part of a vast network, and separating it from that network is not understanding its native function. I have seen what seemed to be miracles, but once I accept that human brain activity is not limited to what is conscious, the miracles are merely unexpected, incredibly unlikely according to ordinary thinking, but ... not involving, say, violation of conservation of energy or physical laws. Part of what the brain does is to interpret reality as good or bad, but that is largely the back brain, operating instinctively and without high intelligence. When we have not distinguished the operation of the back brain, of how it  creates fear and upset, for example, our function can be quite limited. The release of fear is behind much of the idea of high function when "using the full brain." Any personal attachment, including attachment to looking good, being right, even attachment to personal survival, can create a domination of the full-brain activity, making it *relatively dumb.* It's still pretty smart, in some ways, or clever might be a better word. Some of the answers here are based on another version of the question that asked about telepathy or telekinesis. They are not well defined, usually. I can move matter by thinking about it. I just happen to do that through my body! That is, my thinking is part of my body, it is not separable from it. And my body is part of the universe. But I have never seen any substantial effect that I could reasonably call "telekinesis." There are some skilled magicians, though, who know how to create appearances, and I'm not excluding the possibility of extremely subtle effects with microbalances. Which are on the edge of detection and thus suspect of being non-existent, artifacts of unknown experimental conditions. But telepathy is something else. What I have seen, however, all can be explained without some new physical process, simply by unexpected brain function. Example: there is a story that Milton Erikson, the hypnotist, visited a psychic, who told him about his uncle by name. As I recall the story, when he left with his friend, the friend said, "But you don't have an uncle [by that name.] Erikson said, "Right. I was subvocalizing the name, and this psychic had learned to read subvocalization." Now, when I first read this story, I thought that this was evidence that the psychic was a "fake." Maybe. Maybe the psychic did not know where what was arising in his consciousness was coming from. He was "reading" the person. Including subvocalization, but the bandwidth of human presence is far, far higher than the stream of verbal speech. We read people, and, I found, under some circumstances, we know what they are thinking, because we are thinking the same. At least that's how it seems. That is, it is possible to "think together." I've seen an amazing exercise on this, in Landmark seminars, it is called the Colors exercise. Let's say that it is an utterly astonishing demonstration of tight coherence of the mental activity of two people, I don't want to spoil it, because it really is fun! It very much looks like telepathy. So what is it? Is "mind reading" parapsychological if the people are face-to face? What if they are highly connected in some way, such that, even when not directly present with each other, they still are "entrained"? So what is this question about? This is the bottom line: it is possible, particularly with training, to develop what is called "intuition." This is far larger than conscious thought and analysis, but it includes that. Some people think of intuition as if it means that every thought that comes to their mind is intuition. The kind of intuition that means something to me is that we do things that, in hindsight, were more than we knew we could do. It is not about "thinking," i.e., mental chatter, which is part of what limits intuition. It is, when it is in operation, effortless, but it can take effort to turn off what inhibits it! That chatter!

Original question: What would be possible if we had full control over 100% of our brain? Short answer: There is no way for you to control your brain because consciousness is not devoted to control but to keep things balanced (homeostasis) between the different subsystems of the brain. The simple reasons, based on cybernetic theory, are: You would need an external controller (actually, several of them) to control the brainThe controller(s) would be bigger and more complicated than your brainThe data rate for a single controller would be hugeYou would need to simplify the controller algorithms to cope with data rate (bandwidth) and system oscillationsLong answer: Well, the problem with self-consciousness is simple: What are you going to be conscious of your brain with? To be able to have control of your brain you would need another, external brain, that controls your brain, a secondary brain of sorts. This is what, more or less, happens inside your brain: your cortex sort of “controls” the limbic brain and the limbic brain “controls” the brain stem. The brain stem is typical of reptilians, the limbic brain of mammals and the neocortex of primates.  Same goes for computer systems: to control something, a disk array, a chip or whatever, you need an external computer. As you can imagine, the relations between the component of such a, comparatively, simple system are not of “control”: every subsystem plays its part. So, firstly, it is not possible to control 100 percent of your brain: what you think is “you”, is only a part of your brain. To be conscious of your brain you would need a “locus” (site) for that consciousness to reside: an external controller  Secondly, that consciousness or “brain controller” has to be much more complicated than your own “primary brain”. The first person (that I know) that noticed that any system needs a complicated controller sub-system to be viable was Stafford Beer, the Manchester Zen Master of cybernetics. Stafford Beer on viable cybernetic systems, 1971  If you listen to the first 2 or 3 minutes of that video, you would notice that Beer postulates that any system has a complicated control system. Those systems described by Beer can be anything, not only “you”, but many things that behave like a cybernetic system. For example: your brain (your brain is, definitely, a cybernetic system)the social and cultural system in which you livethe corporation you work forthe country you live inThey have, at least, several subsystems: The subsystem that deals directly with the external world (muscles, senses, nerves) or System 1The subsystem that deals with dampening the reactions of System 1, or System 2 (brain stem) to minimize uncontrolled oscillationsThe subsystem that administers or manages the “here and now” of Systems 1 and 2, or System 3 (cerebellum) to make efficient reactions adapted to the restrictions of the external worldThe subsystem that deals with management of future consequences, or System 4 (midbrain) to make predictions that increment your viabilityThe subsystem that balances the here and now and the future that serves as a homeostat of Systems 3 and 4 (cortex) to learn to have long term gains as opposed to short term gains in this “control”As you can understand, your System 5 cannot deal with everything. That is, for example, the reason why you are unable to control even your own body: what controls your body is the cerebellum, not the brain, and you have to “domesticate” your cerebellum for anything. That is also the reason why it can take a couple of years for your cerebellum to play football: your brain cannot control the muscles by itself, it has not the bandwidth. Imagine you having to control every muscle you use to walk: it is an impossible task. You simply, using your consciousness (prospective system) think “I am going to walk”. Your cortex says “Yes, it is a nice afternoon, better take some fresh air” (balancing the needs of your body, that wants to stay at home and do nothing and your prospective system that knows you are growing an underbelly). Now, to be able to actually walk by moving every muscle like a puppet, that’s outside your capacities, as it should be. This would be like a President in a company trying to control every aspect of it, from what every worker do at every workstation to controlling what the lawyers and accountants are doing for mid term control: it is not going to happen in a cybernetic, well balanced, evolved system.

Brain power isn't really something that can meaningfully be quantified in this way, but arguably we already do use 100%, just not all at the same time. (It wouldn't exactly make sense to be making maximum use of the parts of our brain that move our arms when we don't want our arms to move, for example.) See Snopes' Ten Percent of our Brains for a thorough debunking of the claim that we use only a small percent of our brains on a regular basis. It also bears mention that when you see fMRI diagrams like this:   that have only a portion of the brain highlighted, they are showing *relative*  activity: electrical activity is taking place over the entire brain, but different regions are just more active than others when we perform particular tasks. You wouldn't expect to see extremely high activity in olfactory regions when you're not smelling anything particularly strong, for example, but that doesn't mean they're not active to a certain degree. That said, what this question may be getting at is: Is there incredible untapped mental potential that could theoretically be unlocked, if we somehow could discover how? It's certainly possible. For example, Psychology Today has a nice discussion on whether extraordinary autobiographical memory could be the result of "unique experiences that occur during development" ( Page on Psychologytoday ). Psychologists differ widely on whether they believe such abilities are primarily due to genetics, the environment or a unique combination of the two.

You usually use all of your brain, one hundred percent, to live - so, sorry to break this to you : We are not superhuman, with a lack of means to tap into our inner powers. We are just what we are. Nothing more, nothing less. Even during sleep, parts of the brain constantly work. “LUCY” is just a movie, by the way. It is fiction, not fact. It would be best to leave it at that. (If you know what I’m talking about.) Proof? Here (taken from Wikipedia) - Neurologist Barry Gordon describes the myth as false, adding, "we use virtually every part of the brain, and that (most of) the brain is active almost all the time." Neuroscientist Barry Beyerstein sets out seven kinds of evidence refuting the ten percent myth : Studies of brain damage: If 10 percent of the brain is normally used, then damage to other areas should not impair performance. Instead, there is almost no area of the brain that can be damaged without loss of abilities. Even slight damage to small areas of the brain can have profound effects.Brain scans have shown that no matter what one is doing, all brain areas are always active. Some areas are more active at any one time than others, but barring brain damage, there is no part of the brain that is absolutely not functioning. Technologies such as positron emission tomography (PET) and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) allow the activity of the living brain to be monitored. They reveal that even during sleep, all parts of the brain show some level of activity. Only in the case of serious damage does a brain have "silent" areas.The brain is enormously costly to the rest of the body, in terms of oxygen and nutrient consumption. It can require up to 20 percent of the body's energy—more than any other organ—despite making up only 2 percent of the human body by weight. If 90 percent of it were unnecessary, there would be a large survival advantage to humans with smaller, more efficient brains. If this were true, the process of natural selection would have eliminated the inefficient brains. It is also highly unlikely that a brain with so much redundant matter would have evolved in the first place; given the historical risk of death in childbirth associated with the large brain size (and therefore skull size) of humans, there would be a strong selection pressure against such a large brain size if only 10 percent was actually in use.Localization of function: Rather than acting as a single mass, the brain has distinct regions for different kinds of information processing. Decades of research have gone into mapping functions onto areas of the brain, and no function-less areas have been found.Microstructural analysis: In the single-unit recording technique, researchers insert a tiny electrode into the brain to monitor the activity of a single cell. If 90 percent of cells were unused, then this technique would have revealed that.Synaptic pruning: Brain cells that are not used have a tendency to degenerate. Hence if 90 percent of the brain were inactive, autopsy of normal adult brains would reveal large-scale degeneration.Well, isn’t that just interesting?

Can we use 100% of our brains? I hope you are not referring to the myth that we only use 10% of our brain. I for one, have always felt that we use 100% of our brains. Certainly there is no truth to the idea that we only use 10 percent of our neural matter. Modern brain scans show activity coursing through the entire organ, even when we're resting. Although it's true that at any given moment all of the brain's regions are not concurrently firing, brain researchers using imaging technology have shown that, like the body's muscles, most brains are continually active over a 24-hour period. "Evidence would show over a day you use 100 percent of the brain," says John Henley, a neurologist at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. Take the act of pouring coffee in the morning: You walk toward the coffeepot, reaching for the pot, pour the brew into a mug, maybe even leaving room for cream, the occipital and parietal lobes, motor sensory and sensory motor cortices, basal ganglia, cerebellum and frontal lobes all activate. A storm of neuronal activity occurs almost across the entire brain in the time span of a few seconds. An interesting side note, out of all the brain's cells, only 10 percent are neurons; the other 90 percent are glial cells, which encapsulate and support neurons, but whose possible other functions remains largely unknown. The four main functions of glial cells are: to surround neurons and hold them in place, to supply nutrients and oxygen to neurons, to insulate one neuron from another, and to destroy and remove the carcasses of dead neurons (clean up). Scientists have also discovered that glial cells called astrocytes communicate to themselves in the cortex and are also capable of sending information to neurons. So even glial cells are probably in use 100% at the end of the day.

Maybe this answer will be a little disappointing but we are using already the full capacity of our brains . Brain imaging techniques in neurology shows that the vast majority of the brain does not lie fallow. Indeed, although certain minor functions may use only a small part of the brain at one time, any sufficiently complex set of activities or thought patterns will indeed use many parts of the brain. Just as people don’t use all of their muscle groups at one time, they also don’t use all of their brain at once. For any given activity, such as eating, watching television, making love, or reading, you may use a few specific parts of your brain. Over the course of a whole day, however, just about all of the brain is used at one time or another. But if all those parts of the brain are unused, removal or damage to the “unused” part of the brain should be minor or unnoticed. Yet people who have suffered head trauma, a stroke, or other brain injury are frequently severely impaired even a small degree of damage to any region of your grey matter can result in catastrophic neurological declines. According to Washington University “If the average human brain weighs 1,400 grams (about 3 lb) and 90% of it was removed, that would leave 140 grams (about 0.3 lb) of brain tissue. That's about the size of a sheep's brain. It is well known that damage to a relatively small area of the brain, such as that caused by a stroke, may cause devastating disabilities. Certain neurological disorders, such as Parkinson's Disease, also affect only specific areas of the brain. The damage caused by these conditions is far less than damage to 90% of the brain”. Finally....let’s don’t forget the popular quote about atrophy in medicine that says “If you don’t use it, you lose it “.

The myth that you don't use 100% of your brain has been debunked many times.  Not using parts of your brain does not make evolutionary sense. If an area wasn't used for survival, it would disappear over time.  We use nearly 100% of our brains throughout the day, but not all at once. The myth largely came from PET scans that showed low activity in some areas, and high activity in others. Unfortunately people saw these and came to the misguided conclusion that the non-coloured areas on the scans aren't being used (this is completely false). Everything firing in the brain at once would pose serious problems for communications between neurons (as in epileptic seizures). Inhibition of signals is just as important as the actual signals themselves. You need low activity in some areas for the brain to work efficiently in the high activity areas; you can't have everything firing with the same level of activity at the same time. But those areas with low activity will undoubtedly have high activity at some point throughout the day and are therefore not useless.  Unfortunately movies such as "Limitless" have spread the myth that there is some untapped reservoir in our brains. It's funny how if you repeat a myth over and over the population starts to believe it despite your best efforts to correct them.

The good news is that, for practical purposes, we do use 100% of our brain. Let me explain. For decades science claimed man only uses 10% of our brain. This referred to the approximately 10% of the brain’s volume comprised of gray matter. These are the familiar neuronal networks consisting of axons, synapses, and dendrites that carry electrical signals through complex pathways to store and retrieve memories, activate our muscles, and release various chemicals. We measure brain activity by measuring the electron flow or voltage. The white matter, making up the remaining 85% – 90% of the brain, transmitted no electrical signal, hence, scientists assumed, had no ability to communicate. Therefore, this larger portion of the brain has historically been considered structural. That is, its role was to act as a support or ‘glue’ to hold the more critical neural components in place. In fact, the white matter was named glia, a derivative of the Greek word for glue. Recent research has changed that 10% viewpoint. Studies of the glial cells go back to the 1800’s, but through the mid-twentieth century the conclusions from electrical and cellular studies held that neural cells were responsible for all of the brain’s activity. In the 1950’s it was uncovered that glial cells actually communicate through calcium waves rather than electric signals, opening new avenues of chemical research. Today we know that, far from being merely structural, glial cells perform vital functions in our brains. They send signals and communicate. Astrocytes, one of many cells in the glia, can control the firing of neurons at the synapses. Another glial cell, microglia, acts like the brain’s own Red Cross. This tiny cell responds to injuries and clears infections. As humans age, we build dangerous plaque in our synapses. One, beta-amyloid, is considered the main cause for degenerative diseases like Alzheimer’s. When you fall into a deep sleep, microglia sweep away this plaque. The oligodendrocyte, curls its tendrils around neurons wrapping them in a multi-coated myelin sheath. The myelin prevents leakage as signals pass through the neurons and enables them to distribute information faster. Today, scientists agree our brains are capable of utilizing all of its resources. (Though not all at the same time.) An excellent book for more information is: The Other Brain by R. Douglas Fields, Ph.D.

This question comes up so often that I have two standard responses. One of them is about tool use. What counts as using 100% capacity of your car? Going as fast as it can all the time? Loading it with all the weight it can carry and drive it like that all the time? Driving it the most or less fuel efficient way all the time? Driving it only when it is the safest to drive? Driving it only when there's absolutely no other way to reach your destination so it will last longest? What counts as using 100% capacity of your computer? Running it so that your CPU is always nearly 100% loaded? Or your RAM is full all the time? Running it so there's no space left to use of the hard disk? All three at the same time? Keeping it clean with lots of headroom? I believe that trying to answer these questions above will bring us closer to the answer about the brain.  The second response is about how misguided the entire "using our brain" idea is. The act of using something requires minimally that user and tool must be separated somehow. In the case of brain use, user, tool and usage is hopelessly intertwined. Where am I when I use my brain? Am I the user the tool or the product? "Using our brain" is only a figure of speech impossible to translate into capacity measures.

Your question won't have the effect you're looking for in an answer. Evolution of mind-power has nothing to do with quantity, but rather quality. By comparison, lets say you have 1g of carbon atoms, scattered in a “pile”, it would be just that: A useless pile of carbon atoms. Now structure those atoms into a hexagon pattern and you have grafite or diamond. Depending on use, a diamond will more likely come to better use than the pile of atoms, but the amount of atoms in both scenarios are the same, its quality that matters, not quantity. Every brain is used 100% at all times, but there's different degrees of “use”. Most neurons are in a waitstate, they're in “use”, and constantly processing information. Most of the time they process waste information, basically sorting out unsignificant sensory input from the body, the brain itself and the outside world via five senses. What's interesting though is any information processing that is significant, which triggers structuring of new neuron pathways throughout the brain to store, analyze and structure that information as memory “formulas” or modules. The more infomation and knowledge stored, the more structure and the more neurons are occupied to structure leaving less neurons free to do dynamic generic tasks. So - back to quality: if 100% structure would result in 100% quality then 100% quality would result in no free cells left to process new input. Your brain would basically just be a 100% storage unit, it wold be “dumb” / passive and static, no neurons would be free to even complete simple tasks like accessing that memory/formula structure, your brain would be unable to make use of the information there as it would have no free hands. So, 100% use (quantity) is the current state of all brains, and 100% structure would result in a static unusable passive braindeath, you would die from 100% structure, you wouldn't be able to move, blink or eveb breath. So how can we reach the goal your question is really looking for: A superbrain with unimaginable powers, perhaps even mind over matter - or mind over reality itself. The answer to that lies within the formulas. All significant information is stored as knowledge/memory like mentioned earlier, but not all information is the same, so “structure” isnt just structure, there's and infinite amount of formulas that could be stored in our brain, so content and context, the shape/form of the structure/neuron pathways actually matters, and thats what separates a dismond from a pile of atoms, you need the right structure, the exact right formula to develop such a superbrain. Lets reshape your question: “What formula/knowledge/structure would result in a timespace-bending superbrain with unimaginable powers?” The answer to that is: We don't know yet. There are clues to what makes a brain more powerfull within a given scenario/context, a savant doesnt have more use of his/her brain, it doesnt have more structure, it just have different structure, different formulas, most of those extraordinary structures are a result of trauma or injury, either by accident or at prebirth, what we do knownid this: synestesia plays a huge part, stronger connections between sensory neuron clusters or ”centers” that should'nt be there, resulting in leakage from one sensory center to another, blending of sensed becomes a symptom, which is the very definition of synestesia. People with that special structure leading to a high degree of synestesia have proven to produce some extraordinary skills. A person can “taste” numbers, and then perform inhumanly complex calculations by simply tasting since the brain for some reason has a lot easier access to taste-memory than numeric memory, and can distinct a single taste between tens or even hundreds of tastes mixed together in a dish. Numbers are just that; numbers, and numbers makes no use of any sensory stimuli/input, this makes it hard for the brain to work with. The brain works alot faster with sensory input due to the survival urgency needed to analyze your surroundings. The brain was made for survival within its enviroment and at such it proccesses input from its surroundings with urgency, haste, full priority. Numbers and purely “thought” / internal input is processed on powersaving mode so to speak. Calculating what 2+2 is isnt a life or death scenario, tasting or smelling that meat is rotten however is. You basically confuse your brain and trick into look everywhere inside all its centers for where to best proccess your music creation nonsense and to do that it needs to establish permanent connections between all the centers/clusters - this is the closest you get to the term “using ALL of your brain proactive aka 100% simultaniously”. An explanation I once found intriguing was “redundancy”. NASA, Airbus, etc provide 3–5, or more, redundant controllers for one critical operation. Each operation is voted on before being executed. A disagree results in the questionable controller being disabled while the system continues running smoothly under control of the remaining controllers. It's a network of watchers watching watchers, and it works! If our breathing were conducted along one single path of neurons, then the moment one of those neuron died, we would stop breathing. Thank heaven we've been provided with billions of redundantly configured neurons, voting away constantly. I'm sorry, a quick re-read informs me that I didn't carefully read the question. It asked what if we have 100% “Control” over our brain. I apologize. Upon review, I think my notes remain relevant. I'll let them stand, with qualification. I think that having full control would be just as scary. Assuming 100% control is present, I'd ask to what degree is the “controller” informed on the consequences of a single change? Would we know which, exactly, change should be made in order to achieve the single, desired result? I wouldn't be too surprised to find there are millions of connecting, overlapping points between desire and result. A simple example: acting on the desire for ME to be happy, then behaving in selfish ways which minutes or years later, lead to misery. Significant consequences likely would be appearing constantly. We might never be sure of who we're talking to. Well, less sure than now.

In actuality, you should ask what you couldn't do if you used all of your brain at once. Basically, the 10% thing came about in the early days of brain understanding, when a metal rod or some other object pierced the brain and the victim was nearly unharmed.  Doctors surmised because of this that parts of the brain sat unused. In actuality, you do use your whole brain as Dan Holliday mentioned.  But when you are injured, your brain has the ability to "re-route" around damaged areas and rebuild neural pathways.  Some damage can't be repaired or routed around, but much can.  There are a certain number of "reserve" stem cells available for rebuilding brain cells, but by adolescence, your full complement of adult brain cells has been formed, along with a reserve of cells not in use.  This reserve can be used to rebuild damaged areas and re-route around damage if needed.  Using 100% of your neural capacity (active and reserve) would mean that you have no more reserve available for when brain cells die off or are damaged.  This would mean that you would lose brain capacity daily for the rest of your life from the moment that you used 100% of your neural load.

100% of brain capacity? Capacity is a broad term. I will interpret it in a way so that I can make a different answer than the ones already given. I believe there is a better way to use our mind, just like using something based on how it was designed. The best way to use our brain would be the 100%. So, defining that the 100% would be a faster, more precise, creative and intricate thinking, what are the factors that affect thinking speed, precision of thought, creativity, clarity of thought and intricate thinking? Below is the results of my reflections. There is a model behind it, but to simplify I will put the the facets above into perspective. Creativity Please, read Fábio E. Arruda's answer to Where does a thought originate/come to us from? And where does it go back to? so that you understand what I’m talking about. Creativity is the capacity to think outside the box. Creativity increases when you use your pattern recognition without restriction of context. In other words, when you look for similarities between two things without constraining how far those two things seem to be apart. That results in creativity by luck, the ones common children use. (I don’t see how to explain non-luck creativity, which is much more of use, without explaining the whole model by now. Maybe in the future, when that model get more mature…) Clarity of Thought Clarity of thought is how vivid a thought is. Clarity will increase when we increase the intensity of sensations (“emotions”) involved in that thought. Precision of Thought Precision of thought is the specificity of meaning. Precision will increase when we have specific meaning in thought. In other words, unambiguous clarity of thought. Intricate Thinking Intricate thinking is the complexity of thought someone can attain. In other words, working memory. Intricate thinking will increase when clarity and precision are co-existent. Thinking Speed Thinking speed is the distance someone can travel in thought given a time. Thinking speed will increase once you increase precision, as you will not have to correct thoughts on the go; creativity, as it can yield big jumps; the ability to hold complex thoughts, as you won’t have to go back to re-remember the related elements. Those are some facets of what some call intelligence. This is not low-level explanation (no pattern recognition, as in the linked answer), and also not high-level (non-luck creativity). Maybe it is incomprehensive, as it is incomplete, so that I will recommend you to follow Fábio E. Arruda's answer to What is a genius, and who can become one? as I will be update it when I have a mature model.

No one knows what a brain with the full capacity to utilize every possibility ever been observed in human brains could do. The amazing abilities of geniuses, savants and people with synesthesia let us know that the brain is capable of much more than most people ever develop, or are capable of developing. Brain capacity and brain function are two different things. All normally functioning brains are functioning at 100%. That is, doing what a brain is designed to do. Although there are many factors that cause the brain to shift emphasis from one region to another, as long as the shifts are taking place in the right way and at the right time, the brain is functioning properly and at 100%. One example of a shift of emphasis that often makes it appear that the brain isn’t functioning at full capacity is the shift that occurs as a result of stress. Studies show that stress shifts energy from the prefrontal cortex to the hippocampus, the region the regulates emotions. The result is that the functions of the prefrontal cortex (executive functions like clear thinking, decision making, planning and strategizing) are reduced. In such an instance, although the brains is working at 100% capacity and doing exactly what it must to balance and conserve energy, the effect is that the functions that help us be most effective at thinking, planning, strategizing, and decision-making are diminished. This in no way diminishes the effectiveness of the brain, only the effectiveness of the executive functions. At the same time, the effectiveness of the fight or flight survival function is enhanced. The problem comes in when we need to be thinking clearly and making good decisions, but stress levels have prepared us to fight or flee rather than think.

It would be possible to get distracted and accidentally forget to breathe - or maybe the need to continually control the micro-muscular changes to keep our balance when standing would quietly drive us crazy! The subconscious parts of our brain do what they do very well - I doubt that there would be anything to gain by putting all of that automation under conscious control. Imagine that we did that with a car…took out all of the automation and made you do everything manually. You’d have to continually be twiddling knobs to control the fuel flow and the oxygen intake - be opening and closing vent flaps to keep the A/C temperature comfortable - be ready at any instant to see that the car is in the process of crashing so that the airbags need to be set off. You’d have to manually flip the turn signal off and on again to make it flash. A car like that would be impossible to drive! To the contrary, we strive to automate as much of our lives as we can - to REMOVE mundane tasks and hand them off to semi-autonomous subsystems and only control the “high level” stuff. So it is with our brains. Humans are highly evolved to have all of this intelligence - and the more of it we have the better we survive. So if we COULD usefully transfer autonomous systems into conscious control - then evolution would already have done that. Honestly, I think doing what you suggest would be a VERY bad idea.

Don’t be silly. This stuff about only using part of our brains is ill-informed and not supported by any neuroscientist. For starters consider this. The brain uses about 20% of the energy consumption of the human body. That energy is hard come by and 200,000 years ago or so, it was very hard come by. If we only used 10% (or whatever) of our brains at enormous cost in forging and hunting, we would not have evolved. Put another way, any critter whose brain was to big and had useless bits requiring lots of food for energy would never have survived at least long enough to fuel the evolution engine. In fact the brain is remarkably efficient and of course not always up to the complex tasks required of modern humans. That does not mean, of course, that all parts of the brain are used all the time. Different brain bits come into play as needed. There are lots of on-off switches. It also does not mean that we can’t learn new tricks or acquire new skills. If I learn to juggle or play Bach’s Goldberg Variations, that does not mean that some hidden, previously unused part of the brain suddenly springs into action to control these behaviors. The brain multi-tasks and reuses bits or combines old structures to create new skills. If 100% of our brain came into play at once, at the same time, we’d likely die.

It sounds a little Sci-fi’ish now, but I have no doubts that neuroscience will acheive just that sometime in the not-to-distant future. Gene expression is an amazing thing.

I guess your question is motivated by the widespread myth that "Humans use only x% (usually x = 10) of their brain."  Have a look at this article: http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/observations/lucy-film-hinges-on-brain-capacity-myth/ An excerpt from the above article:  “…the brain, like all our other organs, has been shaped by natural selection. Brain tissue is metabolically expensive both to grow and to run, and it strains credulity to think that evolution would have permitted squandering of resources on a scale necessary to build and maintain such a massively underutilized organ. Moreover, doubts are fueled by ample evidence from clinical neurology. Losing far less than 90 percent of the brain to accident or disease has catastrophic consequences. This would allow you to observe the world in a non-physical and non-observable form. It would be great for being able to spy on people or experience a dangerous situation in complete safety. In Buddhism, their is a practice called Tibetan Dream yoga or simply dream yoga. This is a type of yoga which allows the monks to create lucid dreams on command. Based off this practice, we can assume that somebody with complete consciousness control would be able to do the same thing. This would enable us to make productive use of our time in our dreams such as self-teaching and practicing, or allow us to have fun. This would also philosophically give us new-insights and realizations about the nature of god or the fluidity of reality which in turn would make us more subjective in our belief, flexible in our behavior, and more aware in our observations of the world. According to this article I read 10 Amazing Examples of Mind Over Matter - Listverse, its been shown that a well disciplined mind has the ability to create an interesting array of physiological outcomes. This means that a person with complete control of their consciousness could heat their skin to the point of drying cold wet sheets, change personality traits on command, increase or decrease the efficiency of their senses, (smell, taste, sight, etc.) reduce the effects of or cure completely certain diseases, slow their heart rates down to levels only an EKG could detect, assume a mastery of skills through mental visualization, turn off pain receptors, regulate blood flow, an ability to see auroras, (And hence peoples physical, mental, spiritual, and emotional states) and increase the rate at which your metabolism burns calories on command. Complete control of your consciousness would also bring you complete clarity when it came to yourself. That would mean knowing without a doubt what makes you happy or sad. This would also include knowledge of things such as your greatest desires, fears, and why you feel the way you do about whatever life has to throw your way. This knowledge of yourself would also enable you to optimize whatever task you put your mind to. This would include the best way to study, the appropriate social vs. work balance, the right person for you, etc. For most people, they believe the boundaries of consciousness end at the boundaries of your very being. In other words, consciousness cannot control anything outside of the physical body in which it inhabits. Hinduism and a philosophical school of thought called Idealism believes that consciousness (instead of matter) are the building blocks of reality. This is something I also believe. If it turns out that Hinduism and Idealism are correct, then complete control of consciousness would allow you to manipulate, control, and create anything around you. In essence, you would become a god.

I see this question (or a variant of it) on my Quora feed every couple of days, so let me have a jab at how I think it should be answered. Implicit here is the 10% myth – which most people thankfully know by now to be false (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ten_percent_of_the_brain_myth). This whole line of thought has always baffled me. The problem here, as I see it, is that this question appears reasonable, but is so ill-defined that it’s nonsensical. What does ‘using’ the brain mean? First, in living cells, processes are constantly ongoing, obviously. But that’s probably not what ‘use’ means. So the second implication in the question is probably that there is a good way to define activity in the brain. Luckily, there is such a way (in a sense). While neuroscience is still relatively young, with many unexplored frontiers, one of its major breakthroughs was the century-old ‘Neuronal Doctrine’, and subsequent theories. From these, neuroscientists now agree that the brain is comprised of individual cells called neurons, that these are anatomically connect in complex architectures, and that the connection allow communication. Most importantly – we know communication between neurons is most clearly evident in the form of an ‘action potential’ a flux of chemical changes occurring in a given neuron, which leads to rapid changes in voltage, leading to the release of neurotransmitters in the synapse with other neurons. This process can then occur in the next neuron. This is generally viewed as the gist of how information is processed in the brain. So – easy, right? Stick electrodes in the brain, measure action potentials, see their frequency, of occurrence and then we can characterize ‘usage’ of the brain. Not really though… First of all – what would 100% be – constant ‘firing’ (another term for action potentials)? That’s no good; it will not relay any information. Actually, when activity is allowed to run wild in a positive feedback loop, what one gets is an epileptic seizure. That’s definitely not what we’re looking for then. So sometimes it’s exactly when a cell is not firing that it is being used. The balance between excitation and inhibition is unimaginably important in complex brain structures. What I’m getting at here is this – it’s to define the brain’s activity, and it’s even harder to find clear cut correspondences to emergent phenomena such cognition. By comparison, when you have individual taps for cold and hot water in the shower, and you settle on mixture comprising more cold water and less cold water, that doesn’t really mean you’re not ‘using 100% of your shower’ – it just means that the objective of your shower-taking is to obtain a comfortable temperature, and not to maximize water flow. And the brain would be better compared to the water regulating system of an entire country, with billions of valves (and that still does not begin to capture it’s true complexity). This is really the interesting point here – the ‘usage percentage’ question implies a well-known, meaningful, consensual way to relate the brain’s activity to its output (mostly cognitive operations). As of now, neuroscience cannot relate whole brain activity to a single operation in a clear-cut way (and definitely not for all possible functions). By this I mean, we have not obtained an insight such as ‘to produce a memory you need these components and can throw out the rest’. I doubt that we ever will. It may be that the brain’s uniqueness lies exactly in its vast monolithic connectivity. Even more dramatically, it’s possible that a brain must be situated in a body to produce cognition. Anyway – this is the crux of the issue to me. The term ‘use’ assumes we know the relation between neural activity and any or all mental operations. As of now – we don’t. A similar misconception is that each operation corresponds to the activity of a location in the brain – but I guess I’ll get around to answering one of those questions some other time.

But here are some facts, gathered with the help of medical imaging progress:- Most of the brain is active all the time, even during sleep (meaning signals are processed by neurons), but some parts are more active than others when we perform a task- If we really used only 10% of our brain, it would be a huge evolutionnary downfall, as the brain is the most consuming organ in our body (approximately 20% of the total energy while being only 2% of the mass) and it is most likely that natural selection will not have “permitted” such a inefficient organ to stay the way it is Hope it answers your question

I really hate this misconception. 100% of the brain is used, just not all at once. Not all parts of the brain are used for the same function. Why would you use your occipital lobe for speech? You wouldn't. That isn't to say that different parts of the brain can't work in conjunction to help paint the whole picture, but to say that we have this untapped potential is without evidence. You'd be better off saying that our brains could eventually evolve to fit our environment in a more efficient way (which it has already). Brain organization is key, not necessarily space, or how big it is. The more convolutions/surface area (sulci and gyri) the better. People already use 100% of their brains. The idea that we don’t is a myth. perhaps from the time when little was known about the brain. Brain imaging studies show that all of our brain is active, though different parts of the brain will be more or less active depending on what they are doing or perceiving, And damage to any part of the brain will cause some form of impairment, which would not be the case if parts of the brain were lying fallow. We can always learn new things, but this involves making connections between existing neurons, not in using previously untapped parts of the brain. A person who could use only 80% would have experienced quite serious brain damage, perhaps from a severe stroke. The effects would vary according to which parts of the brain were damaged, but they wouldn’t be good.

We use all of it, 100%! Unless, of course, you drink a lot of booze that kills your neurons. (No! FYI that is a myth too. This Scientific American article from 2008 sheds light on this topic:Do People Only Use 10 Percent of Their Brains? "It turns out though, that we use virtually every part of the brain, and that [most of] the brain is active almost all the time," Gordon adds. Furthermore, this TED-Ed animation beautifully traces the putative origin of the myth; and debunks this long-standing myth in terms of high energy expenditure of the brain compared to the rest of the body.What percentage of your brain do you use? - Richard E. Cytowic

The 10% number is a misnomer. What happens is, we already use 100% of our brains all the time, but we don't use all of it at the same time, is all. The brain houses an EM circuit and helps regulate the strong field from the heart. As such, it's very conservative. It only allows roughly 10-20% of glucose to be used by the body at any given time, for instance, which is why serious injury, chemicals an drugs, intense fear and childbirth take such a toll on us. These events exceed the allotment that the brain has set for energy consumption. Evidently, this is also why we have to sleep or else face systemic failure. What you are asking is, what would happen if we were to use the entire brain's reserves at the same time. It's simple: we'd suffer total cataclysmic overload and drop dead.

You already use 100% of your brain. The idea that people only use a small percentage of their brains is a myth propagated by movies, such as “Lucy”. Do People Only Use 10 Percent of Their Brains? Although it's true that at any given moment all of the brain's regions are not concurrently firing, brain researchers using imaging technology have shown that, like the body's muscles, most are continually active over a 24-hour period. "Evidence would show over a day you use 100 percent of the brain," says John Henley, a neurologist at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. Even in sleep, areas such as the frontal cortex, which controls things like higher level thinking and self-awareness, or the somatosensory areas, which help people sense their surroundings, are active, Henley explains. Take the simple act of pouring coffee in the morning: In walking toward the coffee pot, reaching for it, pouring the brew into the mug, even leaving extra room for cream, the occipital and parietal lobes, motor sensory and sensory motor cortices, basal ganglia, cerebellum and frontal lobes all activate. A lightning storm of neuronal activity occurs almost across the entire brain in the time span of a few seconds.

A2A: “How much smarter would we be if we use 100% of our brain? What can we do with that?” I’m an advocate for increasing one’s ability to work by 16X. This comes from the 80:20 Rule idea, where it is thought that 80% of the work in any company is actually done by only 20% of the employees. If one could harness the power of this idea - what could one do with that? I estimated that to mean, as a manager, one increases a person’s ability to work by 16X. I was once hired by someone that trained me on the 80:20 Rule and he wanted me to use this concept to increase the productivity of an Engineering Department. In three months I increased their productivity by 4X. He has said, he only hires 80:20 Rule people, so I was not starting from scratch. This company’s backlog was dwindling fast. In 6 months the owner began laying people off - laying off the people I had trained. As a substitute teacher I tried to apply such ideas to 300 classrooms of students over a period of 5 years, where the classes were only 50 minutes long. I found that if one increases the emotional level of students, by 2X, this will increase their ability to work by 2X. I was able to do this with half of these classes. They completed their Lesson Plans in about 20 minutes. About 2X as fast. So, just increasing your emotional level, being happier, or being enthusiastic, will increase your ability significantly. 2 of these classroom I estimated 4X’d their emotional level to exhilaration. Students in each of those classrooms said they had learned more that day, than from their regular teacher, all year. I estimate that if you increase your emotional level by 4X you may increase your learning ability, your ability to work, at least 4X, what it is now. I found something, for myself, accidentally one day. A clarified a word and a girl that had been failing in math for 7 years now was brilliant in math. She had been doing well in school and then had not been for some reason, unknown to her. When I clarified the word in that area just after she had been doing well, she was doing well again. Now, truthfully, I knew this was possible, I had been told this. But this was the first time I had ever seen this happen right before my eyes. One day I did this, again accidentally, with an entire classroom. The regular teacher had assigned a math puzzle that required a knowldge of all the hard words that she could think of that the students might be having trouble with. It was sort of quiz for me to give. I immediately found that even the best students would not be able to compete this puzzle, unless I did something. So I did something. Each time a student asked a question, I located the word the did not know and helped them define it. I answered them loud enough that all could hear. A bright student had been nudged by a friend needing help. She told him, loud enough for all to hear, “He is telling you all the answers - just listen!” So, one by one, I answered questions and ALL the students completed the quiz. But an amazing thing had happened, now they ALL were doing well. Three students told me that they had learned more in the one class than with their regular teacher all year. So, you could do this one thing to increase your ability to work, or your ability to learn math, or any subject, one-by-one. You might have another student help you as a tutor when you do this. Locate the time you were last doing well in one subject, one subject at a time, say reading. Locate it as closely as you can, right down to the sentence if possible. Then find a word, that when clarified properly, returns you to doing well. This should return you to an emotional level between enthusiasm and exhilaration, and recover any inability to learn that subject, and your willingness to learn that subject, and ALL your understanding of that subject. (Even if you have been failing for 7 years, or more.) I am not saying these three ideas will get you to the “100%” you are talking about, but maybe until then, this will do. Oh, by the way with the 4X in the Engineering Department, I had each Engineer, do the routine tasks they would be doing and repeat them 5X. The first time I did this an Engineer took 3 days to do a task. I arranged for him to do this exact task from another project, it took 2 days or 16 hours. Then 1 day or 8 hours. Then 4 hours. Then 3 hours. He had 8X’d his productivity when doing that one task. But he also learned what it felt like, to work like a 16X person. For students, when they define words or do demonstrations or draw graphs, I have them use this principle, but slightly different. I don’t ask them to do it 5 times. I have them do it till they can do it quickly and easily. This is usually 2 or 3 times. Good luck to you, Leon

I agree with Recchia's answer. I figured you must be referring to that 'we only use 10% of our brain' myth. Think of the problem this way: that ~3 pounds of tissue between your ears uses 20-30% of your whole body's energy metabolism. It would not be very efficient or conducive to survival for the body to build and maintain such expensive tissue and then not use it. So all the parts are there and working, in a normal brain, ready to be used as needed for whatever task is at hand.Now the brain's capacity to do information processing work may be expanded by a process called 'learning'. You learn and retain new information or skills because new dendrites bud out and new synapses form in your brain. Lots of work on early environmental enrichment in rodents indicates that early experiences can have a dramatic effect in improving a person's cognitive capacity throughout life. The upper limit on how much learning a brain can accomodate is not known, but is probably constrained by genetics.

If the question derives from the old myth that we only use 10% of our brain then the first response it that the idea was a convenient myth. It was convenient because we all hope there is a route to superpowers, such as unlocking hidden brain power. The myth derived from two perspectives: 1) early brain stimulation experiments where obvious responses to stimulation were not observed for a lot of the brain; and 2) the observation that neurons contributed to about 10% of brain tissue with glia contributing roughly the other 90%. The reason early stimulation experiments did not show obvious functions for a lot of the brain is that a lot of brain power is actually devoted to very subtle, complex tasks - like extrapolation, inference, abstraction, cross-correlation, generalization, synthesis and other high-order functions. Realistically, we collectively use most of the brain we have, just like we collectively use most of the physical strength, lung capacity, cardiovascular capacity, and so forth. As individual humans we may use much less than our capacity - just as a “couch potato” watching TV is not using muscular or cardiovascular capacity. Obviously, the answer for that is “get off the couch”. The same is true for cognition. Push your limits and you will use as much as you can. You may then expand your limits to some extent. However, unlike muscle function we do not observe that brain capacity (e.g. “IQ”) can be markedly changed by effort. We can become more skilled in using what we have.

I'll diverge a bit from the answers here. While everyone is right that the vast unused portion of the brain is a myth, it is still a myth that persists - probably for the reason that it feels like it is true. One reason for this may be the dual system brain we all use. When we say "I" we are often referring to our conscious (self-aware) brain, which is only a portion of your usable neurons. A good bit of the brain fuction is devoted to non-conscious processes and decision making. I've seen estimates that between 45% and 90% of the choices you make every day are non-conscious, and that doesn't even account for the brain work expended on maintenance systems like breathing, heart beat, etc.  So yes, technically we make full use of the amazingly efficient cognitive machine we call a brain. But because our consciousness lays on top of a much larger non-conscious piece, it feels like there's a lot we leave on the table.  The above is all conjecture. Lots and lots of evidence for non-conscious processing (see behavioral economics or embodied cognition), but I have seen no studies linking the dual system brain structure to the pervasive idea that we do not make full use of our brain. I just think it fits.

[copying from an almost identical question]Once again, everyone misses the distinction between 100% of your brain and 100% of your brain CAPACITY, which is a much more interesting proposition. This would amount to perfect efficiency of neurons, structure, neurochemical function, etc. No one has achieved this that we know of, so there is no basis for comparison.  As an aside, the use of the 10% capacity question was a vehicle in the movie (Lucy) to address a much more fundamental question. If you had godlike powers (omniscience, omnipotence), how would that affect the human condition? What would/could/should you do if you could do/know everything, and would you be justified in that, or any choice.  As usual, people get hung up on trivialities and miss the bigger picture, because they're looking for flaws instead of leveraging what is given into something worthwhile. Which is also a theme of the movie, so I guess they anticipated their own critics. How meta.

Most neuroscientists would laugh at the first question and answer with a clear “no”. Nevertheless, I argue that there are several ways how the “10% hypothesis” could be considered true: Yes, we lose most of our neurons throughout our life, beginning from when we are still in the womb. Yes, not all the brain areas contribute equally to a certain brain state, and yes some brain lesions might leave the patient mind surprisingly “intact”. But that´s exactly how the brain is supposed to work! Let´s give you some examples: In a given moment, cars occupy only 10% of the city grid plan, large empty spaces are not used between two cars. How fast would we go if we cover 100% of the streets with cars? A google search provides you only with 10% of all possible pages that are in the search engine! how much more information would we get if every google search would display all possible results? While running, you use only 10% of your muscles at the same time, alternating between extensors and flexors, how fast would you run if you would contract all the muscles at the same time? I think you got the answer. Yes, we might not use the whole brain, or the whole brain at its maximum computational potential in any given time. But the brain works much like a stone sculpture: you get to what you want by eliminating what´s useless. “less is more” So, you know what would happen if we use 100% of our brain capacity? In neuroscience we call it “seizure”: not much fun.

You are laboring under the false assumption that humans do not use all of their brains. Actually, humans do use 100% of their brains unless they have been injured and lost part of their brains in the accident. It is not that we fail to use all our mental power, but that many of us lack the cross-connections of dendrites between neurons within our brains. Most people lack critical thinking skills, memory capacity, creativity or sensitivity that they would otherwise use. Getting these abilities is always possible if only the person would take the time and use their energy to enter into neurogenic activities so that their brains will develop the dendrite cross connections they need. Doing puzzles, solving mazes, answering questions (like here in QUORA) and arguing in debates are all ways to build dendrite cross connections within your brain.

To me the idea that humans only use a small percentage of our brain is a myth. The brain is divided into specialized sections or has designated duties. Example- if your eyes are closed then you are not seeing. If you are not seeing then the vision center of the brain is on standby. If you are not eating then taste is on standby, etc. Each activity uses a special set of brain centers but not all of them at the same time. I f someone used MRI or some other test to study brain function, it would appear that a large portion of the brain was inactive. It wasn't inactive but just on standby until needed for a certain task.Some really interesting work has been done with people who have lost parts of their brain in accidents or from disease. The intricacy of brain function is almost beyond comprehension.

This question is based in a myth. In a way, you do use 100% of your brain, just not all at once. No matter how much you are using at any time, it has to be less than half for the simple reason that the other half needs to be available to receive the next packet of information and process. It works by conveying information back and forth. To use it 100% as you are thinking would be like filling a room with people and having them all talking at the same time. No one is listening. Nothing is actually getting processed. Now if you bring the room to order and say, wait your turn or at least listen and respond to only the immediate people to your right before picking a direction to address your response to the next group of people. Some may be busy doing something else and not even notice the communication. Some will bring up something entirely different. Some will inject new ideas… This is how the brain works with billions of neurons and trillions of connections in groups of specialists. You can’t run all the circuits at once as nothing is conveyed or processed when you do. Therefore the goal is to optimize the use of your mind, not to use the most.

Nothing, because you already have full access to your brain. What do you mean? Evolution does not create extremely expensive neural machinery just for it to sit around and go unused. That would be immediately culled out of the gene pool, if any embryo/person started doing that, because it would be very very non-adaptive. The only reason you don’t constantly “use” every part of your brain is that not every part of your brain is relevant to every task. The same reason you don’t use “all of your kitchen utensils at once” — using a blender and a fork and a coffee grinder and an oven and a microwave and a meat tenderizer all at the same time! isn’t going to make “the tastiest meal ever!” it’s just going to make a hopeless, wasteful mess. Similarly, there’s no useful purpose for using the memory of where you parked your car while you’re trying to make tea. It’s not helpful. In fact, it’s anti-helpful, it’s distracting and confusing. Nor is it helpful to use your skill at stunt biking while having sex, nor your knowledge of Spanish when you’re in Norway, nor your neurons that make your left leg flex, when you’re trying to go to sleep.

response.answer_text: We actually can use our entire brain, we just don't use it all at once, because we have no need to. Different parts of the brain have their own duties, but they don't all perform them at once. Some wait until you're asleep because they aren't suppressed by your conscious mind then. The idea that we only use “10%” of our brains or whatever is completely false. Humans do have abilities that come out in extreme conditions, usually because of adrenaline and other substances flooding the system. Some abilities are enhanced in situations because the brain suppresses them to a degree normally since they aren't necessary for everyday life, but that's not us using only a small part of our brain all the time. Most people don't need the strength to lift a truck in everyday life, so the brain suppresses that ability so that you don't expend more energy and resources than absolutely necessary for life.

The brain is an organ. The neurons that create it and the cells that support these neurons are always doing something. If you’re referring to how on MRIs perhaps people may see it as if parts are dormant or inactive then this is not exactly as it seems. These ‘inactive’ blobs are sinple significanty less active than all other parts of the brain and so do not show up as colored splotches. To further this, the entire idea that your brain only activates certain parts when certain situations arise (You begin to read therefore your ‘reading center’ of the brain activates) is already misguided. Many parts will be used more frequently at one monent in time to complete even the simplest of tasks, however do not forget that all parts are still active. Thank you for the question! According to a survey from 2013, around 65 percent of Americans believe that we only use 10 percent of our brain. But this is just a myth, according to an interviewwith neurologist Barry Gordon in Scientific American. He explained that the majority of the brain is almost always active. The 10 percent myth was also debunked in a study published in Frontiers in Human Neuroscience. One common brain imaging technique, called functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), can measure activity in the brain while a person is performing different tasks. Using this and similar methods, researchers show that most of our brain is in use most of the time, even when a person is performing a very simple action. A lot of the brain is even active when a person is resting or sleeping. The percentage of the brain in use at any given time varies from person to person. It also depends on what a person is doing or thinking about.

This is a common misconception these days. We do use 100% of our brain capacity, we can't afford to have 90% of our neurons just slacking off. If that were the case, we wouldn’t be an intelligent species, and that wouldn’t be a word. I can tell you that most of the answers you are going to get will be very insensitive, and I am warning you ahead of time. But to be useful, I will answer the question as if we did use 10%. We would most likely be able to have much more control over our cells, and be able to think at speed close to that of a computer. Though We wouldn’t be able to use telekinesis, because that is against the laws of physics, and just impossible no matter what your brain capacity.

The brain weighs 3 pounds, uses 20% of the energy demands of the body. Any given snapshot of the brain shows between 10–15% of the brain being active, a stimulating conversion over 10 minutes results in about 40% of the brain being active, while as much as 100% of the brain is active over a 24 hour period. Even so, there is a lot of merit is using more of the brain at once, or even more of the trillions of neuroconnectors at once. Striving to excel is always great on so many levels, but its hard to say exactly how far any of us will eventually be able to grow as a species. There are probably so many things that have influenced our evolution over many millennia. The fossil record suggests that we have been evolving quicker over the last five thousand years by as much as seven percent. Scientists have suggested as we solve more problems, such as microbes and viruses, we will have less reason to evolve in the future, so we may need to take charge of our own evolution at some point. Right now the only control we have over self-evolving is through life’s experiences, and even though it is more of a biological function to pass on good genes, it also serves to actuate genes. See my BLOG for more info: Enlightenment, the Whole Shebang Blog!

There’s a lot more that we don’t know about the brain than we think we now know, and there is no way to prove that we are currently not at maximum capacity. Not too long ago, glial cells or glia, were thought to be “only” support cells — they cleaned the bathrooms, took out the trash, got everyone up for work each day, and made certain that everyone had enough rest and enough to eat. Glia represent about 50% of brain cells, neurons make up the rest. We now know, and have known for a while, that glia do much more than regular maintenance. They are, instead, charged with maintaining the health of neurons and other glia; protecting cells under attack from alien invaders; coordinating rescue activity for neurons under siege and so much more. They do the heavy lifting. Check it out: The Other Brain: The Scientific and Medical Breakthroughs That Will Heal Our Brains and Revolutionize Our Health by Fields Ph.D., R. Douglas It’s a great resource for professional and non-professionals and a good read. If you’re interested in how the brain works with dementia, schizophrenia, and other pathological brain processe, you might even find it fascination. I have no association with the author.

You already are. The notion that a human being uses only 10% of his / her brain is a myth. Enough scientific advances have taken place to show that every part of the brain is indeed carrying out some function or the other. Depending on the architecture of the neurons in various parts of your brain, they are assigned numbers termed as “Brodmann areas”. For example, when you are seeing this message on your screen, Brodmann area 17(the primary visual cortex) is active & so on & so forth for virtually every part of the cerebral hemisphere. With the advent of functional MRI & PET scans, neuroscientists can directly observe which part of the brain is activated by a particular stimulus. Still having doubts? Just think about this : A rippling body builder decides to avoid the gym for a year. What would happen? His muscles will simply atrophy because they are not being used. Similar principles apply to neural tissue. If you were indeed using only “10%” of the brain you were born with, then 90% of it will simply atrophy & you would still be using 100% of your remaining brain!

We don’t ‘think’ with our brains but with our minds. The brain has certain functions in order that we can think (as we call it), many of whose locations within the brain are known to modern science. the brain is hardware. The hippocampus, for example organises long term memory, other parts of the brain look after short term memory. The old limbic brain stem is the oldest part of the brain. It is believed to look after, fight or flight reactions. So the brain is necessary but in and of itself it is not sufficient for thinking, unless you subscribe to the notion that thought is ‘content’ in the form of ‘representations’ ensconced ‘somewhere’ in the brain and functioning as electric impulses forming synaptic connections to memory neurons where memories are formed and held in situ till called upon to become conscious. We do read each others minds. Every time you discuss a topic, you shape your response to achieve a certain response, the one you want to achieve, we mirror one another, in actions like taking similar postures; folding arms, touching our faces, placing our hands on hips, all these, in a social context are non-verbal signals, also known as phatic communications (I like you, you like me), that we unconsciously share with others, especially those we are amicable towards, we even have signals to let people know we don’t like them. We share a common language, It is not your or my language but a shared community of speakers and using this common form of communication we know what there are saying and what they mean (unless of course they are trying to deceive us). Super human powers belong in comic books and the ‘hero’ movies. There are however, folk with remarkable skills. others who can do incredible things like remember every event in their lives in detail, but this turns out to be a curse, as they are never fully conscious to their present lives, they ruminate over past events, as their immediate ‘real’ life passes them by.

I really really really don’t like this myth. Mainly because I’ve seen what happens when our brain “works at 100%” - that is, when all of our brain activates at once. They’re called grand mal seizures. We use all of our brain. The myth that we only use 10% of it is a misunderstanding. What it means is that we actively only use about 10% of our total brain at any one time. There are parts of our brain that regulate various involuntary processes in our body that are operating pretty much all the time, but we don’t actively use them for the processes we tend to think of as “thinking.”

At once? All of the humans all at once collectively used all of their brain at one time?  7.356 billion people (the current population of Earth) would have a seizure.  A pretty serious epileptic seizure at that. I would definitely not recommend anybody fully use their brain at any one time, for any reason whatsoever. Inhibition of communication between neurons is just as important as firing between neurons.  But this question is likely asking something else. Specifically:"Does using ALL of our brain make us smarter?"Even if we ignore the severe seizure that would come about from doing so, the answer would still be no. The amount of memory and information every human holds in their brain is immense, and an attempt to 'notice' every function and memory at one time would be impossible to comprehend. The parts of the brain responsible for waking and sleeping would be running at the same time.The motor pathways for running and walking would be activated at the same time.Every usually independent function of the brain would paired with a likely incompatible function, resulting in nothing particularly good for both your mental and physical capabilities.

QUESTION: If we have 100% access of our brain, what will happen to us? ANSWER: It’s happening to you (and everybody) every day. We already have “100% access of our brain.” That nonsense about people using only a fraction of their brain is just exactly that - NONsense for the gullible. It was a mistaken interpretation of what somebody said, decades ago. The brain has a variety of functional areas that are in states of more or less activity due to current need for their specific function, and that varies as the day goes on, and your actions make more or less demand on a given portion of your brain.
