The 10 percent of the brain myth is a widely perpetuated urban legend that most or all humans only use 10 percent (or some other small percentage) of their brains. It has been misattributed to many people, including Albert Einstein. The popular notion that large parts of the brain remain unused, and could subsequently be "activated", rests in popular folklore and not science. Though mysteries regarding brain function remain—e.g. memory, consciousness—the physiology of brain mapping suggests that all areas of the brain have a function. Sight (vision), hearing (audition), taste (gustation), smell (olfaction), and touch (somatosensation) are the five traditionally recognized senses. The ability to detect other stimuli beyond those governed by these most broadly recognized senses also exists, and these sensory modalities include temperature (thermoception), kinesthetic sense (proprioception), pain (nociception), balance (equilibrioception), vibration (mechanoreception), and various internal stimuli (e.g. the different chemoreceptors for detecting salt and carbon dioxide concentrations in the blood, or sense of hunger and sense of thirst). All parts of the brain are used, just as all parts of the electrical grid are used. The local volumes show different levels of activity, depending on what is happening in the brain. The demands of a specific part of the brain can be measured using positron emission tomography (measures glucose uptake rates) and fMRI (measures blood flow). We can also monitor the rapid changes in activity throughout the brain using electroencephalography (relatively old technology) and magnetoencephalography (a newer and faster technology). We can make movies of brain activity from these imaging techniques. When played, we see activity moving from one part of the brain to another. Even a simple stimulus causes activity that rapidly moves around, taking in all of the brain.

False premise, as others in this thread have noticed.  Serious brain researchers say that while we perhaps  don't use our brains as efficiently as we might, there's no evidence we  have vast unused abilities. Admittedly no one has ever tested all the tens of  billions of neurons in a given brain. You've certainly got a few spares;  otherwise no one would recover from a stroke. But attempts to map out  the cerebral cortex, the center of the higher mental functions, have not  found large areas that don't do anything. The general view is that the  brain is too small (just three pounds), uses too many resources (20  percent of body oxygen utilization though it accounts for just 2 percent  of weight), and has too much to do for 90 percent of it to be  completely comatose." - Cecil Adams, Do we really use only 10 percent of our brains? This old fallacy is repeated so often. It simply cannot be the case that we only use a small percentage of our brain. We are often using only a certain percentage, because that’s the bit which is necessary for the task we are currently engaged in. But five minutes later we are doing something different, and a rather different subset of our neurons are firing. Big brains are frighteningly expensive in terms of nutrition and upkeep. There really isn’t much chance that we have anything which is not at least occasionally required.

There are people who purport to have total control over mind and body, not to mention a measure of control over the outside world that verges on the supernatural. If you're curious, you'll want to research Tibetan Buddhism, Bön and the practice of Dzogchen. Note that these people don't necessarily exercise 100% control of everything at any given moment, just that there is little they can't control when and if they want to. Such people use this control to pursue a spiritual perfection that will let them break free of the passions and become one with the universe. Any power or control that seems magical or superhuman is called a siddhe and is usually regarded as a curiosity on the way to the Great Perfection, not an end in itself. In other words, if you could take total control over brain and body, you'd find there are more important things to do with your time.

Dr. Ano Nymous who is credited for being the researcher who originally discovered that people only use 10% of their brain was misquoted. There are several excellent answers saying that the question’s premise is invalid. But there is another way to interpret the question so that it makes sense. What would happen if we were willing to accomplish 80% or more of the things we are capable of doing? What if we were all more disciplined and thoughtful? What if we could discard bad habits and cultivate good ones? What if we were kinder and friendlier to the people around us? What if we strove to have correct views rather than assuming that we are already have them? What if we made a better attempt to understand other people’s points of view before dismissing them? None of this would require more brain capacity but it would require us to make better use of that capacity. We might have a better political system, more successful marriages, fewer unemployed, better technology, less war, and much more. It wouldn’t be paradise but the world would be a better place.

There is a role for other types of thinking (ideas about spirituality, for instance), but if we don’t appreciate our Cognitive Biases or we cannot think our way to a more accurate understanding of the world we can easily go down the paths of ignorance, bigotry, and irrationality. As a past British Prime Minister said, it’s ‘…education, education, education.’

As other people have said already, this was misquoted originally. Something else to think about relating to this topic: There's a concept called use it or lose it. If only 10 percent of the nerve cells in your brain were being used the other 90 percent would die. After all, why should your body devote energy to keeping billions of cells alive when these cells aren't being "used"?

The idea that we use less than 100% of our brains is a persistent myth. Neural tissue is the most expensive (in terms of metabolic resources required) in the human body - do you think the process of evolution would allow us to grow a very large, extremely expensive organ some large portion of which is never used? Do you have any fingers or toes that you never use? The whole conjecture is patently ridiculous.

Your brain is like a specialized V-10 automobile engine that runs continually while you are alive. It has different levels of power use, when you are asleep it may consume 15 watts, and when you do sudoku it may top out at 25. You always use 100% of the engine, but at any given moment only 10% of the pistons (neurons) are firing. A greater percentage of firing would decrease performance. A brain's performance can be enhanced by stimulant drugs such as caffeine, and transcranial magnetic stimulation can be used to shut down certain brain centers which quite consistently will enhance mental abilities in other brain areas.

We do. We actually do. But much of it is doing things automatically (the autonomic functions). Imagine if we had to consciously control our breathing. Or tell our brains what sounds to discard as we attempted to understand what someone was saying. Or directing each muscle consciously as we balanced our body while walking. Your body does so much automatically at the behest of the brain. You can feel heat and cold, understand what you are touching. Having complete, conscious control over our brains would be a nightmare. We would have to deliberately choreograph every action. But it does make for wonderful science fiction, doesn’t it? Imagine being so in control of the brain that you had X-ray vision! Except it doesn’t work that way. Our eyes receive light. We don’t send anything from our eyes to probe the surroundings. Or imagine being able to move things telekinetically. You might imagine it. You just can’t do it. Moving things requires physical force, and the mind is not connected to the outside world except through your body. There are reasons that mentalists have regularly been exposed as frauds. Granted, there is much we don’t know about the brain. But we know physics and chemistry. And superhuman powers or X-men abilities or mutants who transform reality with their mind just don’t exist. We all want to be more than we are. But if we make the most of who we are and work hard to learn and understand the world around us, we can do some pretty remarkable things.

Fact - pound for pound the brain uses a large multiple of the calories used by e.g. red muscle. Resting the brain is a necessary economy. Revving up the brain such as to study, think, plan, design, etc. coincides with the rest of your body going into a resting state. Marathoners may do casual arithmetic about liters of water and miles to go, but they don’t solve quadratic equations in their heads. Nature / GOD’s design / evolution / what-have-you tends to be very “smart” and economical in just about everything. Just like pumping iron or working out on the track, you can ‘train’ your brain. In fact, learning to ride a bicycle does that. Learning to study does that. Learning to play a musical instrument does that. The net truth is that our brains are trainable, but not nearly as expansive as we hope.
